name: Matteo Kimura
headline: Applied Computational Math @ Caltech | Co-founder @ Atum Works (YC X25) | Lunar Trailblazer Intern
summary: Student at Caltech interested in space, robotics, systems engineering, and mathematical modeling.

experience.title: Lunar Trailblazer Mission Operations Intern
experience.description: The Lunar Trailblazer mission seeks to redefine space exploration with an optimized, low-cost approach that addresses key scientific questions about lunar water and lays the groundwork for water-based in-situ resource utilization on the Moon. My work focuses on automating procedures to streamline spacecraft operations, enabling safe and reliable flight with minimal staffing and reduced complexity. This involves developing custom tools for spacecraft maintenance, validating system requirements, and preparing to serve as a systems operator during the mission's flight phase.

experience.title: Co-Chair
experience.description:
Managing and supporting the current activities and future growth of the largest undergrad-led aerospace organization at Caltech. Working to enable unique educational opportunities for students through hands-on projects.

Responsible for helping raise and manage >$200K in funding, establishing/maintaining collaborations with organizations at Caltech (JPL, KISS, Brinson) and with industry, and supporting a wide variety of student projects.

experience.title: LATTICE/CHARIOT Systems Engineer
experience.description:
LATTICE (Lunar Architecture for Tree Traversal In-service of Cabled Exploration) is a self-deployable cable-way system designed to transport payloads into and out of lunar craters. After winning the Visionary Concept Award at the NASA BIG Idea Forum, I have been leading efforts to advance the system, with the goal of deploying it on the Moon as CHARIOT (Cable Haulage and Asset Robotics for Infrastructure and Operations Transport).

I organized a rooftop demonstration at Caltech to showcase LATTICE’s "rim-to-rim" implementation, which supports five times more payload mass than the original design, while promoting the ME75 class that further developed the concept.

Currently, I am building a roadmap for technology maturation, collaborating with science missions like the Lunar Crater Radio Telescope and industry partners such as Honeybee Robotics to explore both near-term science applications and long-term infrastructure development.

experience.title: PILLARS Systems Engineering Team Member
experience.description: Helped with ideation, connecting with industry and academic experts, and developing traceable requirements and system verification for a NASA BIG Idea 2024 proposal. The concept, PILLARS (Plume-deployed Inflatable for Launch and Landing Abrasive Regolith Shielding), was awarded 150K by NASA to develop and validate our system.

experience.title: NASA Extreme Terrain Mobility Challenge Shuttle Subsystem Co-lead
experience.description: I helped lead the roadmapping, manufacturing, testing, and iteration of the LATTICE Shuttle System (a self-tensioning cable riding robot designed to move heavy payloads into and out of lunar craters) so that it could reach completion. I also worked with the team to ideate the future steps of our project, estimate long term lunar risks for the project (micrometeorite risk, cable creep analysis, etc). I also attended the NASA BIG Idea Challenge Forum to present our system to leading industry engineers (NASA, Honeybee Robotics, Astrobotic, etc.) where we won the Visionary Concept Award.

experience.title: NASA Extreme Terrain Mobility Challenge Autonomy Team
experience.description: I worked on determining strategies for controlling the LATTICE Shuttle System (a self-tensioning cable riding robot designed for moving heavy payloads into and out of craters). I developed a state space model for the physics of the shuttle to simulate different control schemes to determine the most optimal means of controlling the robot. I also setup a code repository that enabled the rapid development of drivers and system code while having automated unit testing to automatically verify key functionalities.

experience.title: Brenda and Louis J. Alpinieri SURF Fellow
experience.description:
I helped develop a second version of the LEONARDO (LEgsOnboARDdrOne) robot with updated
hardware to provide a serviceable test platform for future autonomy research with this system. To do so I had to rewrite firmware drivers and troubleshoot various hardware and software issues in order to integrate the new hardware. I also added and verified software failsafe mechanisms to ensure safer testing of this system.

experience.title: NASA SEES Peer Mentor
experience.description: I served as a Peer Mentor for the 2021 and 2022 NASA SEES Earth Explorer Interns to help them plan and execute their research projects. I also helped organize the Adopt A Pixel Project for both years where 100+ interns would collect in-situ and remote land cover data on nearby areas of interest to collect valuable land cover data to verify high resolution landcover maps. To engage the interns, I built a web dashboard to visualize the data and compare it to high resolution land cover maps like ESA's Worldcover map.

experience.title: Intern
experience.description:
Worked alongside NASA Science Leads to create Python procedures to clean and flag GLOBE Observer Mosquito Habitat Mapper and Land Cover datasets.

Presented our work at the CitSciVirtual conference under the Data and Data Management and NASA Citizen Science categories in addition to participating in Q&A sessions to further discuss our work with other citizen science researchers.

experience.title: Co-President
experience.description: In May 2020, I became co-president of the team. During the height of the pandemic, we determined ways to keep doing robotics by learning Computer Aided Design and hosting virtual outreach events such as a virtual workshop with the University of Brasilia. As in-person competitions began again, I helped keep our momentum going by helping fundraise $7,000+, hosting a 30+ person robotics camp with the Art of Problem Solving Academy, training new members, and leading the development of the team's first fully CADed, vision-based, and custom machined robot.

experience.title: Software and Controls Lead
experience.description: I led the software and controls for my school's FIRST Robotics Competition Team. I had to fill this role as a freshman spending 20-40+ hours a week programming our team's robot in Java, learning basic control theory, Git version control, and design patterns. I led the integration of closed loop controls for the first time in team history. That year our team ranked 33rd in the state of Texas and qualified for the Houston World Championship.

I experienced the synergy between this unique set of skills that Matteo embodies first-hand when I worked with him at the Institute for Global Environmental Strategies (IGES). There, I quickly learned that he is not only able to emerge with salient, robust solutions to complex problems but also able to lead his peers with unwavering focus and fortitude. Matteo embodies a rare yet impeccable array of leadership, engineering, problem-solving, and analytical skills that I'm sure will prove him to be an essential asset for whatever project he chooses to work on.

recommendations.recommenderHeadline: YC X25 | Princeton
recommendations.text:
Ayush is a rare gem, a veritable Swiss Army knife of talent who brings more to the table than a Thanksgiving feast. His work ethic is so strong, it could bench press a Buick, and he goes the extra mile more often than a marathon runner. Speaking of that, given his rotund figure, he should perhaps run one or two!

Ayush's quick wit and adaptability are like a chameleon on caffeine, allowing him to navigate any situation with the finesse of a ballet dancer in a minefield. He's the ultimate team player, always ready to lend a hand or a well-timed joke to lighten the mood. Ayush's attention to detail is sharper than a laser-guided scissors, ensuring that no stone is left unturned, no i is left undotted, no t is left uncrossed, and no donut is left unassaulted. He's the epitome of professionalism, with contributions that are more valuable than a truckload of gold-plated chocolates. But he should lay some of those chocolates off, eh?

But hold your horses, folks, because once Ayush gets started, he's like a runaway train with a rocket strapped to its back. He's a force of nature, a supernova of potential, and a genuine asset to any organization smart enough to snatch him up. So, giddy up and get ready for the ride of your life, because Ayush is about to take you on a one-way trip to success! But that trip is NOT a one-way to fitness!

name: Mathis Joffre
headline: Building the infrastructure for AI Agents @Blaxel
summary: An agent operates a remote VM via MCP! Blaxel is a cloud infrastructure built for agents. At the heart of this cloud are Blaxel Sandboxes, which provide agents with access their own virtual computer(s). They are agentic by design: the entire VM is exposed as a simple MCP server. Your agents can read/write files and run shell commands as simple tool calls. Blaxel sandboxes shut down after 1s of inactivity (and we snapshot the running memory). Upon receiving any request, they boot in less than 25ms and resume the processes state exactly where it was left off. Here's a demo of connecting to a Blaxel sandbox using MCP and making tool calls with a simple LangChain agent. We built the first operating system as-a-service for agents. Try it today on Blaxel. - Sign up: https://app.blaxel.ai - Sandboxes SDK: https://lnkd.in/eWAe4PpC - Code examples: https://lnkd.in/e9ubfVdt The AI revolution won't wait. Neither should you.

name: Paul Sinaï
headline: Co-founder & CEO | Serial Entrepreneur | Successful Exit | Building the Future of Cloud for AI
summary:
With over 13 years of experience in the cloud and data analytics field, I am passionate about creating innovative and scalable solutions that empower businesses to leverage their data and gain insights. As the VP of Analytics Products at OVHcloud, a global leader in cloud services, I lead a team of product managers, engineers, and designers to deliver cutting-edge analytics platforms and applications for our customers across various industries and regions.

Before joining OVHcloud, I was the CEO and CTO of ForePaaS, a company that I co-founded and grew from a start-up to a successful multi-cloud and automated platform as a service for data analytics applications. OVHcloud acquired ForePaaS in 2022, recognizing its value and potential as a game-changer in the cloud and data analytics market. At ForePaaS, I was responsible for setting the vision, strategy, and roadmap for the platform, as well as overseeing the technical, operational, and financial aspects of the business. I also led the development and launch of several innovative products and features, such as the ForePaaS AI Studio, the ForePaaS Data Lake, the ForePaaS Data Processing and many other products. I leveraged my skills in cloud applications, big data, and business intelligence to create solutions that enabled our customers to build, deploy, and scale their data analytics applications faster, easier, and more securely.

name: Marcello De Bernardi
headline: Co-Founder & CTO @ Plexe AI (YC X25)
summary: We are not a fast moving company — and we’re proud of it. When the stakes are body-cam footage, evidence integrity, and prosecution in court, speed for speed’s sake is reckless. That’s why Code Four (YC X25) ships secure and reliable before it ships fast. We're proud to do things that don't scale. We hop on planes, sit with every user, and won’t leave until their first report flows end-to-end without a hiccup. To honor that commitment — and the people who inspire it — Dylan Nguyen , Natnael K. , and I are spending Memorial Day hand-delivering donut boxes to 30+ departments around the bay to thank them for their service. We're still en route. Want us to swing by your precinct? DM me and we’ll pull up.

recommendations.recommenderHeadline: Machine Learning Engineer at Expedia Group
recommendations.text:
I had the pleasure of collaborating with Marcello multiple times during his tenure at EG. He brings a strong balance of technical expertise and leadership, making him a standout team player and mentor.

One of Marcello’s greatest strengths is his ability to wear multiple hats when needed—whether stepping in as a hands-on individual contributor or providing strategic guidance as a tech leader. He adapts seamlessly to the needs of the team and the organization, always ensuring progress without compromising quality.

Beyond his technical skills, Marcello fosters an environment of learning and growth. He empowers his team by providing guidance with trust and autonomy, allowing them to take ownership and develop their skills. His thoughtful leadership and problem-solving mindset make him an invaluable asset to any organization.

I highly recommend Marcello for any future role he chooses to pursue. Any team would be lucky to have him.
recommendations.relationship: Sheetal worked with Marcello in the same group

recommendations.recommenderHeadline: Manager of Data and Machine Learning Science | Machine Learning
recommendations.text:
I had the pleasure of working with Marcello for over three years, during which he played a key role in our team's success—first as a Machine Learning Engineer and later as a Manager leading a team of over ten engineers.

From the start, Marcello proved to be a valuable asset, bringing the right level of technical maturity and expertise to take on the productionization of our machine learning models. His deep understanding of ML— particularly in sequential and learning-to-rank models — was instrumental in ensuring the robustness and scalability of our solutions.

When he transitioned into a managerial role, I was truly impressed by how seamlessly he adapted. Leading a broad team of engineers, he demonstrated exceptional leadership, strategic thinking, and adaptability in a dynamic environment. We worked closely to ensure our team’s throughput—quarterly planning using Gantt charts, allocating resources based on skills and expertise, tackling blockers, and remaining flexible in shifting priorities.

Marcello’s combination of technical excellence, leadership, and professionalism makes him a rare talent. It has been a privilege to work with him, and I have no doubt he will continue to achieve great things. Any company would be lucky to have him!
recommendations.relationship: Giorgio worked with Marcello in the same group

recommendations.recommenderHeadline: Senior Machine Learning Engineer @ Expedia Group
recommendations.text: Marcello was my manager when I joined Expedia Group. He did an exceptional job onboarding me and helping me navigate the company. What truly stood out was his ability to guide me toward what matters most, which significantly contributed to my initial growth. Marcello's balance of technical expertise and leadership skills made him not just a good manager, but a valuable asset to the entire team and company. His approach consistently empowered team members while maintaining a clear focus on our goals. I highly recommend Marcello without reservation and I'm confident he has everything needed to succeed in all his future endeavors.

Always works great under pressure and always thinks on his feet to provide solutions for any last minute blockers or risks that may arise. I would definitely recommend Marcello to any future employers and or organisations, he is an asset to any team he joins.

He also wrote code to customize the behavior of the product to solve important scenarios that were blocked in the past. He showed a 'can do' attitude and a willingness to go the extra mile to make the customer successful. It has been a pleasure to work with Francesco and I look forward to do so again in the future.

recommendations.recommenderHeadline: Dynamic CMO & Advisor | Building Breakthrough Brands
recommendations.text:
Francesco is an amazing team player, skilled developer, and a positive thinker. Always calm, even under pressure, but most importantly, consistently eager to lend a hand.

During our time working together, I instantly liked the fact that he loved the product and was extremely interested in making it better according to the end user needs. I was impressed with his keen eye for detail, and how quickly he was able to grasp the technical concepts and factor them into the product planning.

Francesco is a cheerful chap, extremely polite and friendly, with a strong sense of responsibility. Really great to work together. Every successful organization needs someone like him.
recommendations.relationship: Rod worked with Francesco in different groups

recommendations.recommenderHeadline: Games, Consultant C Suite, Focus on Production
recommendations.text:
Francesco was one of the lead developers at Sgame Pro especially focused on the App/Client development that would be the wrap within which all Sgame services would sit. This was a highly complex role as the App was not just a graphical UI but managed an array of functionality beneath it, which he was responsible for.

This included the delivery of games via the App; cyrptocurrency management/rewards for the players and the developers of the games; community tools such as profiles, rewards, friending, social media notifications and more; the "challenging" mechanism which allowed players to challenge each other to in-game tournaments and wager crypto, a major task all on its own, a huge list of other many other tasks as well.

Francesco comes from the classic mould of hugely smart and talented developers who just get on and do the job. A quiet guy but who when he does talk and comment on the tasks, design or overall deliverable you would be very silly not to listen to. He is incredibly insightful and can see issues well before they develop, any PM or Producer not listening to him is setting their project up for future problems.

Quiet he may be but he has a great sense of humour, Italian by birth but with the sarcasm of a born and bred British man. His English is perfect, better than most English people I know. Well respected by his colleagues and able to fit into any team I would think Francesco would be a great asset to any development team looking for someone who gets the job done, brings huge smarts to the table with a quiet confidence of someone who knows they can let their performance and output do the talking for them. I'd be more than happy to give a personal reference for Francesco.

name: Supreet Deshpande
headline: Co-Founder and CEO, Y-Combinator, Ex-McKinsey
summary:
AI Agents for Pharma GTM
Activity
4,318 followers

2024: Dreaming of working with YC founders 2025: Celebrating my 1st angel investment getting into Y Combinator ! Here's how it happened... I was working closely on content marketing for Cactus (YC X25) with my amazing clients and good friends Ajith Govind Satheesh and Avinash Joshi . I got to know these founders inside and out. Their vision. Their work ethic. How they never gave up. I saw how they prioritized company culture, making sure everyone—from engineers to interns—felt valued and heard. I could see something special. I made a decision that surprised everyone—including myself. I decided to put all of my savings and invest in the company. It went from writing their content to writing them a check. At that time, there was no YC backing. Just pure belief in the founders and what they were building. Then a few months later, Ajith messaged me: "Umme I have something to share, can you hop on a call?" My heart was pounding. Good news? Bad news? With founders, you never know. These two got on the call with huge grins on their faces. I paused. What could it possibly be? And then they both shouted: "WE GOT INTO Y COMBINATOR!" I was shocked. Not just at the news, but at how they took the time to personally celebrate this moment with me. I wasn't their biggest investor, but these humble founders made me feel like family. If you're a founder who didn't get into YC—maybe you don't need it right now. Maybe you need to believe in your vision enough that others start believing too. Grateful to Ajith Govind Satheesh and Avinash Joshi for this incredible journey. Here's to many more 🚀 PS: This shows how seriously we take our clients at Social Narrativ . We don't just work with you, we believe in you and invest our energy into your success. If you need personal branding services, DM "BRAND" to join our waitlist. Bookings open June 15th. PS: Found this post wholesome? Repost and share with others.

recommendations.recommenderHeadline: Experienced Data Analytics Engineer at iPipeline
recommendations.text:
I was blessed with the opportunity to work with Supreet on the practicum project with Ryerson at the Institute for Advanced Analytics. The practicum project is an eight-month-long project working with enterprise-level data and enterprise-level problems.

Supreet is ahead of his time when it comes to problem-solving, always being sure to keep a client-focused approach, and having a passion to dive into data. Any time we were in an early or brainstorming phase, you could be sure to find Supreet at the white board. He does such a great job of visualizing and explaining his thought process and explaining the problem. Supreet often made challenging problems very easily digestible - and he enjoyed it too! Additionally, Supreet is the highest level Excel wizard that I have ever met (one of those people that asks, "Why would you use a mouse?"). Along with all of these skills, Supreet is extremely proficient in the areas of machine learning and Python.

One of my favorite things about working with Supreet was his calm nature and ability to act as a mediator. Often when there was a disagreement with the team, Supreet was able to see both sides of the argument and present opposing views in a new light capturing all of the pros and cons of each choice.

I will dearly miss my time with Supreet but hope that our paths will cross again in the future. He is an absolute rock star, and any team would be beyond lucky to have him be a part of it.

I highly recommend Supreet , and hope to find myself working with him again in the future!

recommendations.recommenderHeadline: Maximizing impact through analytics
recommendations.text:
I worked with Supreet on a high-pressure project at ZS Associates, with widespread impact for our client and short timelines. Supreet was a critical factor in the project’s success – his expertise in Resource Planning Optimization and Analytic Tools allowed us to work efficiently and arrive at a strong recommendation that received the full support of our client.

Supreet demonstrated his expertise in Optimization very quickly, both in the quality of his analyses and in the questions he raised as we discussed the ideal approach. Communication is another strength for Supreet, who conveys ideas clearly in both verbal and written form, and is quick to clarify points before confusion sets in.

Supreet was a dedicated, motivated team member who continually exceeded my expectations on productivity and timelines. Given the urgent nature of the work, this allowed us to focus more energy on a few key questions from our client. This was appreciated and recognized at our client as well as internally, and led to a result we were all proud of.

I would recommend Supreet to anyone looking for a strong, capable teammate who is dedicated to solving challenging problems in a cooperative fashion, while having a bit of fun along the way.

name: matthew blackburn
headline: co-founder @ auctor (YC X25)
summary: We closed an $84K annual contract right after the first call. The secret is alarmingly simple. If that’s all you saw, it would feel like pure luck. But that moment was just the tip of a sequence. About a month and a half ago, my co-founder xinan rahman showed a Salesforce veteran what we were building at Auctor . He resonated immediately—and invited us to speak at his conference. “I wish this existed when I was delivering implementations,” he said. At the conference, we ran workshops. Not to sell. Just to share what agentic delivery makes possible. We met someone there who had lived the same pain— And out of pure generosity, they shared our story on LinkedIn. No ask. No prompt. Just support. From that post, someone else reached out. One of the most forward-thinking implementation leaders we’ve met. We had a call. We showed the product. And just like that—signed an $84K annual contract. Not because of a clever pitch. But because the pain was real, and the solution finally made sense. It sounds impossible. But zoom out, and it’s actually simple: 👉 Build something people want. 👉 Talk to people who’ve felt the pain. 👉 Let the right conversations unfold. The moment might look like luck. But the momentum is earned.

name: Anthony Sky Ng-Thow-Hing
headline: Co-Founder @ Auctor (YC x25) | Ex-Apple, ServiceNow
summary: I got hit by a car a week before our YC launch. What most people don’t know is that it wasn’t even our first emergency. A month earlier, my cofounder had a life-threatening allergic reaction. He ended up in the ER, struggling to breathe. We didn’t tell YC or our angel investors. Not because we were hiding, but because we wanted to prove we could handle the pressure. We shipped features from hospital beds. Reviewed code between doctor visits. Sometimes launching means praying your cofounder lives long enough to hit deploy. We launched on time. Twice. He’s okay now and I’m okay now. And the product we built, Willow (YC X25) , didn’t just save time. It helped save us, by making my co-founder work even when he couldn't type. Try it now: WillowVoice.com

summary: 🚨One of the first things we do when onboarding a new customer to Anvil: We analyze your technical foundation to ensure you win in AEO / GEO. Why? Because if we can’t crawl it, neither can an LLM. And if an LLM can’t access it, it can’t reason about it, personalize it, or generate anything useful from it. What can you do about it: Regularly test your website for crawl-ability, scrap-ability, and use of JSON-LD schemas! A combination of Google, screaming frog, and any scrapability test software would do the trick. Your knowledge base shouldn’t be a locked filing cabinet. If users (or AI) can’t find the right answer, it doesn’t exist!

name: Rohan Radhakeesoon
headline: Co-Founder @ Capacitive (YC X25)
summary:
You’ve likely felt the pain of constantly switching between internal platforms (Slack, Jira, Microsoft Teams, GitHub, Asana or whatever else you or your company may use), gathering, inputting, and updating information.

We help companies securely access all their internal knowledge in one place, allowing them to chat with all their data, automate workflows, and reduce time context hunting. We also allow for this data to be granularly permissioned and run through AI tools such as Cursor, Meeting Assistants, or any other AI workflows, giving them the necessary context for optimal performance.

From SaaS to fintech to healthcare, we help teams reclaim thousands of hours by eliminating the 40% of time lost switching tools and hunting for context.

Reach out to learn more about our other features, end-points, and use cases - rohan@capacitive.ai

name: David Yu
headline: Co-founder & CEO, YouLearn (YC X25)
summary: We built the World's First AI Agent for Teachers. It's used by professors and TA's at University of California, Riverside and Holmes Community College . And now, it works in Canvas LMS . Teachers have fallen in love with the way we integrate so seamlessly into their grading process in Google Classroom and Docs. But to be honest, our Canvas integration still sucked. It got the job done for overall feedback, but what students need in order to actually improve, is pinpointed, specific annotations on sections of their work. That's why today, we're announcing Smart Annotations in Canvas. If you're a college professor, teaching assistant, or just happen to use the Canvas LMS at your school, we think you'll love this. VibeGrade (YC X25) is the only grading tool that actually: 1. Saves the teacher time 2. Increases scores by delivering better, actionable feedback 3. Works directly in your existing platform, like Canvas or Classroom. Teachers and students love it. If you're a school that wants to: 1. Improve teacher quality of life 2. Help students improve 3. Be at the cutting edge of AI for education You'd be failing our education system by not giving it a try. This is just the beginning. We'd love to partner with your school to make education better for everyone.

name: Daniel Martinez
headline: High School dropout, Founder @ VibeGrade (YC X25)
summary:
I went from winning the Highest Academic Achievement Award in grade 8, to dropping out of high school. Now I'm on a mission to revolutionize education.

I’ve built full stack software since age 12, currently building VibeGrade, backed by Y Combinator.

We’re the world’s first AI Agent for teachers. Teachers use VibeGrade to turn hours of grading papers into seconds, with the click of a button. We work where teachers work, like a Scantron for Essays. We give teachers their time back, help them deliver better feedback and reduce bias. So far we've saved teachers 500+ work days grading 15,000+ essays, and we're just getting started.

Teachers love us. We're the only platform where teachers can provide a detailed breakdown with specific comments in one click. No need to download/upload essays, setup a complex rubric, etc. Just one click.

name: Brian Y. Kim
headline: Co-Founder, CEO at Kestral (YC X25), Helping Sales <> R&D work in sync
summary: Sales leadership is often times a thankless game. You're charged with hitting the numbers, if you don't, you're gone. If you do - numbers go up, good job. You can help people grow in their careers, you can help them make more $$$ than they've ever made before. But if something changes, ooh they can turn on you fast. Market gets tougher. Company pivots/makes some changes. Selling get a bit harder. All that good will can go quickly. People love you when things are good. People hate you when things are bad/hard. Naval Ravikant said it so well 'In leadership you are often times just ONE decision away from mutiny' Your goal as a leader is ver simple in my mind. 'Make your people better and help them accomplish more than they coud on their own' Not everyone is going to like you. Not everyone is going to be your friend. But if each and every day you're striving to help make them better and achieve more? That's all you can do. Those that understand it and appreciate, those are your people. Those that just want the world without being willing to give/grow/adapt/change/invest, you can't win them over anyway. But keep going ya'll. Keep pushing. Keep GROWING as a leader, and it will pay off in the long run.

recommendations.recommenderHeadline: Manufacturing Engineer Associate Manager at Lockheed Martin
recommendations.text: I am writing to give my full recommendation for Jeevesh Konuru. I’m a Senior Manufacturing Engineer at Lockheed Martin and I worked directly with Jeevesh during his internship at Lockheed Martin in the Summer of 2018. His determination, creativity, and problem solving skills were tremendous, and Jeevesh was more than eager to help our team determine and enact solutions to address repetitive manufacturing defects. During my time working with him, I assigned him one of the projects which I was working on with the objective of greatly reducing repetitive failures on the aircraft. The particular component of the aircraft which Jeevesh worked on was one of the top defect drivers for the year, and his work identifying the root cause, and defining an appropriate corrective action in the short amount of time he had greatly exceeded my expectations. Jeevesh hit the ground running, almost as if he had been doing it for years. He wasted no time, immediately speaking with Mechanics and Supervisors on the manufacturing floor, other Manufacturing Engineers, and Design Engineers to learn more about the process, and determine all possible root causes. Jeevesh’s ability to collect, interpret, and present both qualitative and quantitative data about the components under investigation allowed him to differentiate potential root causes from non contributing factors, and share knowledge with other Manufacturing Engineers so that they could look for the same defects occurring elsewhere. I know that he spent many late nights and early mornings learning Engineering specifications, advanced metrology techniques, and observing processes which only happened during second or third shift. On more than one occasion I personally asked Jeevesh if he could come in on a weekend to help with something and he agreed without hesitation. One trait about Jeevesh which stuck out to me more than anything was how much he enjoyed his work, and learning new things. This eagerness to learn, to work with other team members, and to help solve problems is why he was so successful during his time with Lockheed Martin. His root cause analysis was incredibly thorough, identifying and investigating multiple root causes, and determining their possible effects on the outcome of the part. The corrective action plan which Jeevesh coordinated and implemented to address the high impact root causes which he identified will make a substantial improvement to the component he set out to fix. Jeevesh’s dedication, creativity, problem solving ability, and personable attitude will make him a valuable asset to any organization or group which he is a part of. I have no doubts that these traits will serve him well throughout his career and allow him to succeed at anything he attempts. His work as part of our Manufacturing Engineering team at Lockheed Martin was invaluable, and I wish we could have had him as part of the team for longer.
recommendations.relationship: Mark worked with Jeevesh in the same group

name: Caitlin Hogan
headline: Building better data infrastructure for scientists
summary: 🚀 Hello, Automated Nanoindentation! I’m excited to share a major leap in how we probe the mechanical behavior of materials: automated nanoindentation. 🔬 Why nanoindentation? It’s one of the most important tools for mapping hardness, elastic modulus, creep, and excavation resistance at the nanoscale. By pressing a diamond tip into a surface and recording load-displacement curves, we can extract precise information about how a material deforms - down to individual grains, phases, or thin films. ⚡ The inefficiency of grid-based tests. Traditionally, we raster a grid of indents across a sample. But what if you only care about a specific microstructural feature—say, a precipitate, a grain boundary, or an inclusion? Or if you want to sweep through a combinatorial library to see how composition affects hardness? And when you need to correlate indentation data with EDX maps or EBSD grain‐orientation information, a uniform grid wastes time and data. 🚀 Our automated solution At UTK, Vivek Chawla and Stephen Puplampu have taken the same autonomous workflows we pioneered for STEM and SPM—and extended them to nanoindentation. We now have: - Real-time image analytics to identify features of interest (grains, interfaces, phases) on the fly. - Deep kernel learning models that predict which indent locations will yield the richest insight. - And are exploring combinatorial exploration routines that seamlessly integrate indentation, EDX, and EBSD, so you get multi-modal maps in a fraction of the time. 🎥 In this short video, Vivek Chawla and Stephen Puplampu walk through our system in action—showing how automated nanoindentation can transform your mechanical characterization workflows. And this is done *without* any specific API - so you can too! Special thanks to National Science Foundation (NSF) MRSEC Center UT Center for Advanced Materials & Manufacturing (CAMM) for supporting this work and building the connection between machine learning and physical tools for materials discovery! Check it out and let us know what you think!

I'm a co-founder of Opusense AI, where we’re transforming how engineers and inspectors generate field reports. Our mobile-first platform uses AI to turn voice notes, photos, and typed shorthand inputs into polished, professional reports saving hours of admin time and ensuring consistency across teams.

I have a PhD in Civil Engineering and a background in AI-driven infrastructure systems. My research focused on event detection in water distribution networks. recommendations.recommenderHeadline: Développeur - EPITECH Paris - Entropi
recommendations.text:
Ethan est une personne qui m'a énormément inspiré par son parcours entrepreneurial et sa capacité à innover et à diriger une équipe. Ayant eu l'occasion d'échanger avec Ethan lors de plusieurs événements, j'ai pu apprendre de son parcours, de son engagement, de sa rigueur, ainsi que de son approche face aux défis qu'il rencontre quotidiennement.

Ethan se distingue non seulement par son esprit entrepreneurial aiguisé mais également par sa capacité à transmettre ses connaissances et son expérience. J'ai personnellement bénéficié de ses conseils, ce qui m'a permis de développer mes compétences et de changer ma vision des choses. Sa disponibilité et sa volonté d'aider les autres sont des qualités rares qui font de lui une personne très appréciable et un très bon leader.

J'ai également eu l'occasion de collaborer avec Ethan sur l'organisation d'un talk entrepreneurial lors duquel il a pu partager son expérience avec de nombreuses personnes. Il a su captiver son audience et partager de manière efficace son parcours captivant.

name: Pablo Jiménez de Parga Ramos
headline: Helping 30+ businesses create 5 sales opportunities every week with difficult-to-reach prospects | co-founder @throxy | YC X25
summary:
I’m Pablo👋

I created Throxy after 4 years of being in sales and realising it’s broken.

- 80% of sales teams time NOT being spent selling
- Having to bounce between 10 different tools
- Empty pipelines and empty promises from agencies

We understand that outbound comes down to 3 things:

1. Contacting the right people
2. Making sure emails land in their inbox (and not spam)
3. Messaging that gets people to reply

So…

1. We don’t rely on ZoomInfo or Apollo, we look at where your prospects exist and create unique lists
2. We handle all the technical setup, diversify email infrastructure and regularly check and test deliverability
3. We craft concise, prospect-focused messaging that feels personal and relevant

And through this process we have helped our clients achieve results like:

✅ Imnoo (manufacturing software) consistently booking 5 sales calls every week
✅ Santillana (leading education platform) achieve an 84% positive reply rate
✅ Pycad (medical software) get 15 hours back on their outbound

If you’d like to achieve similar results from your outbound then you have 2 options…

1. Send me a DM saying “outbound”
2. Copy and paste this link: https://throxy.cal.com/gtm/strategy-call

Hope to speak soon!

name: Rayan Garg
headline: Co-Founder, CEO at Theta (YC X25)
summary: I’ve scaled 2 companies to millions in ARR 10+ years apart. Here’s what’s changed: - Last time: PLG drove revenue back then. - This time: Growth is sales led now. PLG is too competitive and crowded, there’s no chance to differentiate. Good people telling stories on demos will scale faster. - Last time: Junior people were hired to take up responsibility. - This time: Senior people with GPT = no need for as many junior people. - Last time: Back then news articles were king. Getting cited in the WSJ changed your month. - This time: Getting into mass media doesn’t matter. Going viral on LinkedIn can make your quarter. - Last time: Back then, it was a given that contracts were annual. - This time: Now, way more people expect monthly contracts as a default. You have to make the strong case for annual. And, you have to constantly fight to keep the customer. You can’t take them for granted. - Last time: A good idea with mediocre talent was enough. You could build a moat and sustain it for a while. - This time: Today, it’s too easy to build products and people will catch up unless you have good people constantly seeking the edge.

recommendations.text: During my time as a Master's student at the prestigious Georgia Institute of Technology, I had the unique opportunity to collaborate with Land. In all of my interactions with him, I have found him to be the epitome of generosity and dedication. Indeed, it is without hesitation that Land's is one of the most kind-hearted and committed individuals I have had the good fortune to encounter throughout my academic journey. Together, we embarked on various assignments, encompassing elaborate projects and regular homework tasks. We also joined forces to prepare for examinations. During these academic pursuits, one characteristic of Land's consistently stood out - his remarkable calm under pressure. Despite our work's rigorous and demanding nature, I cannot recall a single instance when Land succumbed to stress. His resilience is underpinned by an exceptional work ethic; he persistently pursues his goals, demonstrating a steadfast determination to see each task through to completion. One of our most challenging projects required us to delve into the intricacies of programming and mathematical modeling. This was a demanding endeavor, testing our academic abilities to their limits. However, a twist of fate had Land return to Thailand in the midst of this task to attend to some personal formalities. Despite the physical distance and the distractions of his circumstances, Land remained an integral part of our team. Unyielding in his commitment, he worked relentlessly, contributing significantly to our project from across the globe. His effort exemplified his dedication to his work and his ability to adapt to unforeseen circumstances, an essential attribute in today's ever-changing world. Land's contribution was the lynchpin for the successful completion of many of our academic undertakings. His reliability, exceptional technical aptitude, and unfaltering dedication were instrumental in facilitating our achievements. Land was the cornerstone, the steady force that propelled us forward in the face of adversity and uncertainty. Furthermore, I would say Land is a remarkable individual who has made a lasting impact during my time in graduate school. His warmth, dedication, and relentless pursuit of excellence are qualities that are not only rare but also highly desirable in any professional setting. I have no doubt that Land will bring the same degree of commitment, skill, and positive attitude to any future endeavor he undertakes.

name: Aaron Yu
headline: CTO at QualGent (YC X25) | Ex-Google
summary: Shoutout to the unsung heroes behind Google I/O 2025 - the engineers whose work doesn’t make it to the keynote reel but without whom the show wouldn’t happen. The AI breakthroughs and slick product demos may steal the spotlight, but behind the scenes are countless hours of debugging, internal reviews, and complex tooling gymnastics. I know because I’ve been there. During my 5.5 years at Google, across 3 different teams at Android XR, Quick Share and Stadia, I worked behind the curtain - fixing last-minute issues, unblocking partner teams, and enabling those magical on-stage moments you see once a year. I earned 5 spot bonuses and 14 peer bonuses along the way, not because of flashy work, but because I helped make things work. On deadline. Sometimes into the night. Under intense scrutiny. And always knowing that if we did our jobs right, no one would notice. That experience of living inside Google’s release infrastructure, and seeing the real cost of getting high-quality software into users’ hands became the spark that led me to build QualGent (YC X25) . Because great engineers shouldn’t have to fight flaky tests, incomplete QA coverage, or guess whether their release will hold up in the wild. So this post is a thank you - to every engineer staying late to get a build out, writing one more test, fixing one more bug so the next moonshot can fly. You’re the reason I/O is a success. And you’re the reason I started QualGent. #GoogleIO #Engineering #QualGent #ThankYou #SoftwareQuality #BehindTheScenes #DevTools #StartupStory

experience.title: Data Scientist

My duties ranged from pure data science to pure chemical engineering. I resigned my position when Solugen generously offered a voluntary resignation package that anyone could take; I took it.

With data science:
i) I used Bayesian Optimization (BO) to optimize chemical reaction systems; in one case, I dropped the cost of goods sold by 2/3.
ii) I wrote an Excel addin in VBA and Python that would let any scientist at Solugen do BO just by opening Excel, as they would any other data analysis.

For chemical engineering:
i) I did process design,
ii) I did absorber unit sizing,
iii) I used Aspen Simulation software to examine VLE, off-gassing, and aid with design requirements.

experience.title: Graduate Researcher
Process Projects Engineer
experience.description: My duties entail process design, debottlenecking and analysis. My day-to-day work comprises simulation and modelling, writing P&ID's, and reviewing existing designs.

experience.title: Researcher
experience.description:
I am developing and optimizing methods of stabilizing pre-synthesized nanocatalysts in ordered mesoporous supports. The ordered mesopores allow for facile mass transport of reactants and products, and lock the nanocatalysts in place, to reduce nanoparticle sintering and agglomeration while preserving activity.
I have detailed and studied several mechanisms for doing so, and have targeted various key variables.
I design and execute experiments on the basis of these variables.

I've used my engineering background to improve the lab. I was detailed enough to observe that a recently purchased chiller-pump unit would produce too much pressure for a our rotary evaporator ("rotovap"). I produced a pressure control system based on splitting and throttling flow (and the Bernoulli Equation) to make the pressure inside the condensing coils of the rotovap acceptable.

experience.title: Intern
experience.description:
As an intern at General Motors, I worked to increase the stability and cycle life of Li-ion batteries for their EV fleet. The bulk of my time was spent on a project working with electrochemical materials, artificial solid-electrolyte interfaces and Plasma-Enhanced Chemical Vapor Deposition technology to drive up the stability of Li-ion batteries. I took the initiative to increase the efficiency of my laboratory, including introducing MATLAB code to rapidly compile and analyze data in place of using Excel, which would crash from simply loading the data files.

I spent time compiling global data on EV and battery technology to extract trends, followed by making them easily consumable, for the purposes of industrial planning.
Finally, I compiled and organized large number of patents, to produce information on where the technology of the industry was going and make further predictions.

experience.title: Affiliate
experience.description:
I investigated Sn as a battery material. With Li-ion intercalation, it has a theoretical capacity of 994 mAh/g. However, it has been shown that the SEI (solid-electrolyte interface) formed is unstable and is reformed with each cycle, reducing stability and use. Using Sn single crystals, I determined first that the (100) and (001) planes were differently stable, and second that the absence of oxygen or an oxide layer made the planes equally stable.

I also took the initiative to increase the safety and efficiency of equipment in the laboratory, including redesigning several electrochemical cells to increase ease of assembly and safety. They now require less Lithium metal and LiPF6, both of which are safety hazards when the cells must be removed from the glove box, and are expensive to boot.

name: Ramakant Yadav
headline: IIM Bangalore || Ex-Microsoft || Ex-CTO at Survey2connect || IIT Patna
summary: To all the young founders trying to build the next unicorn: You aren’t Mark Zuckerberg. You aren’t Balaji, Sam, or Naval. And that’s okay because you DON’T need to be. The era of VC-fueled unicorn fantasy is dying. You don’t need a Series A. You don’t need TechCrunch. You don’t need 10X growth at 10X burn. What you do need is a profitable, high-margin, bootstrapped business that allows you to live the life YOU want. Take it from someone who has: • Failed 2 startups • Burned $500K in VC • Spent years chasing unicorn fantasy I now run a $10M SaaS, 100% bootstrapped and my life has never been better. The real unicorns in 2025 are small, profitable and 100% owner-controlled. Build that. - A founder who learned the hard way.

name: Sergio Bergmann
headline: Co-Founder & VP of Engineering @ Mesmer (YC X25)
summary:
I’m a second-time founder and engineering leader passionate about building from scratch, solving real-world problems, and helping teams scale with clarity and purpose. Over the past 15+ years, I’ve worked across fintech, crypto, and digital product startups—leading engineering teams, launching new products, and mentoring founders through startup accelerators in Brazil, the US, and now Europe. I care deeply about the intersection of technology, product thinking, and human coordination—and I’ve seen firsthand how alignment breaks down as companies grow.

Today, I’m co-founder and VP of Engineering at Mesmer (YC X25). We’re building an AI operating system for product development—helping founders and CTOs stay on top of what’s happening across engineering, design, and product work without drowning in meetings or status updates. Mesmer gives growing teams the context they need to stay fast, flat, and focused. I’m based in the Netherlands with my wife and son, and always open to connect with builders, dreamers, and people rethinking how we work together.

name: Nikolas Huebecker
headline: Building something new.
summary: Your brain has limited processing power. Every mental task steals energy from your actual job: ❌ Learning dashboard interfaces ❌ Remembering where metrics live ❌ Translating data into decisions This cognitive load isn't just inconvenient. It's expensive. Our embedded GenBI solution eliminates these hidden costs by: ✅ Placing insights directly in your workflow ✅ Using natural language you already understand ✅ Automating the translation from data to action When your brain isn't wasting cycles on dashboard navigation, it can focus on what really matters: Making the right business decisions. The most valuable technology isn't what does more. It's what requires less. #CognitiveLoad #DecisionMaking #GenBI #DirectToInsights #EmbeddedBI #EmbeddedAnalytics

projects.name: Chiron
projects.description: Chiron ( Project Chiron ) is an iPad app that understands math as it’s written - like Grammarly for algebra. The Booth brothers, James Booth and Max Booth are both Oxford math grads, have tutored for a decade, and are set on making human-quality AI tutors a reality. Throughout their education, they experienced firsthand the stark difference between active, exploratory learning— which significantly accelerated their understanding— and passive lecture-based methods, which often proved ineffective. Chiron is built on the principle that AI tutors can only achieve human-quality effectiveness when actively engaged with the student's thought process. To achieve this, the app uses symbolic logic to validate math handwriting instantly, providing direct, actionable feedback in real-time.

These manual processes cost lenders – and ultimately their borrowers – $12,000+ per loan ($61B+ per year). AI can automate 99% of mortgage operations, and Chestnut is setting out to do just that. Besides Ashley, the AI loan officer assistant, Chestnut's agents also help clients find their best mortgage option, cut borrowing costs with automated origination, and notify clients when rates drop. Chestnut is currently licensed in Texas and Colorado, helping clients with home purchases, refinances, cash-outs, and home equity lines of credit. recommendations.recommenderHeadline: Co-founder at Carbonfact
recommendations.text:
I recently worked with Bryan on two DevOps projects: deploying a BullMQ stack on Heroku and migrating a PostgreSQL database to GCP Cloud SQL.

Despite not being initially familiar with our stack, Bryan successfully delivered the projects on time and within scope.

I particularly appreciate how Bryan focuses on delivering the right solution rather than just doing what’s asked. He thoughtfully challenged our implementation plans and proposed alternatives that were better suited to our current situation, aligning with our values of simplicity and pragmatism.

I recommend Bryan without hesitation. He is a highly skilled engineer with a broad range of technical expertise. Bryan is dedicated to ensuring the success of the project and genuinely cares about how the work is handled. He makes sure the requirements, goals, and scope are clear and aligns with your work practices, such as communication and workflow rhythm. Additionally, I trust Bryan with security practices, and his advice is always valuable.

name: Sergey Yudovskiy
headline: Transforming Enterprise Compliance and Automation with AI
summary:
I’m a tech entrepreneur with roots in Kazakhstan, now based between Austin and San Francisco. Over the past 15+ years, I’ve built companies across AI, automation, and infrastructure — from scaling a B2B ISP to $5M ARR without venture capital, to co-founding ElectroNeek, a globally recognized RPA platform featured by Forbes, Y Combinator with the W20 batch, and the Inc. 5000.

In my latest venture, I’m building WorkDone (back in YC with the X25 batch) — a GenAI copilot platform designed to prevent costly compliance and documentation errors in healthcare. We’re pioneering multi-agent AI systems that help hospitals and clinics avoid mistakes and stay aligned with clinical and operational standards in real time.

My work bridges the worlds of automation and intelligence. I was among the first in the RPA space to integrate Generative AI into real enterprise workflows. I believe we’re entering a new era where AI copilots will power a smarter, more compliant way of working.

Let’s connect if you're building in AI, compliance, healthcare, or automation — or want to trade thoughts on what’s next.

experience.title: Chief Product Officer
experience.description: WorkDone helps clinics and hospitals prevent denied insurance claims by tracking documentation and operational standards in real time. Its multi-agent AI system detects gaps, engages staff instantly, and ensures every requirement is completed—without disrupting existing workflows.

experience.title: Chief Executive Officer
experience.description:
With my team and co-founders, we built from scratch an RPA (Robotic Process Automation) platform that is now among the TOP15 in the world, with a large customer base across North America, Brazil and LATAM, and the EMEA regions.

Leading both the business and technological areas of the company, I inspired the team to build a classic RPA development suite and transitioned the platform into the BPM (Business Process Management) space, as well as into the cutting-edge areas of LLMs (Large Language Models) and GenAI with our own Document Recognition and Processing product. I have always played an active role in the product side, especially in bringing innovations.

While the team focused on direct enterprise sales, I established a new approach for partnership sales, securing strategic alliances with companies like Pax8.

Under my management, the company signed significant customers like Xerox, Ricoh, ABBYY, UFP, American Call centers, various local government entities, and multiple mid-sized businesses.

During this short period, I led multiple large-scale RPA projects for top banks, construction, and mining companies, each with over $1 billion in revenue.

EXIT: The company was sold to a local system integrator, who continued working with customers on the ERP side.

name: Lalit Kundu
headline: building | ex-Staff Engineer at YouTube | ACM-ICPC world finalist
summary:
I work strategically as an area tech lead for a team of 45+ engineers in Youtube. Previously I've built core payments backend for Google Pay India app. My ultra-fast growth as an engineer (staff engineer in 6 years) has been fueled by my passion for building products, finding the right problems to solve, and investing in my leadership skills. I give back to the broad software engineering community through 1:1 mentorships, newsletters, and educational content creation on LinkedIn and TikTok.

I previously had a deep interest in competitive programming. During college, I proved myself as up to the ultimate challenge by qualifying for ACM-ICPC world finals, aka olympics of programming. In addition, I also invested in uplifting Indian competitive programmers—hosting specialized training camps, coaching the Indian team for IOI (ioinformatics.org), simplifying complex concepts via tutorials, hosting various programming contests as a judge. I still reap the benefits of the programming and collaboration skills I learnt during that time.

Building LineWise to reduce machine downtime and improve operation efficiency.

Meet Wenbo, an engineer who has been trained in AI, computer vision, and robotics. Wenbo is an enthusiastic AI practitioner and a dedicated roboticist with a strong entrepreneurial spirit. experience.title: Founding Software Engineer, Investor
experience.description:
Company Intro:
✔ Greyscale AI is a product inspection startup building advanced technology for the non-contact inspection of package seals used in the food, beverage, and pharmaceutical industries.

Key Contributions:
✔ Identify food contamination problems in food packages. First Engineer in the company before officially launched. Take initiative to develop AI algorithms to detect and classify food contaminants. Solution deployed to 5 well-known food companies. Reduced food waste by 20%.
✔ Contaminant Detection in X-ray Images. Prototype contaminant detection algorithms in X-ray images using OpenCV; write Computer Vision Module in production code using C++; optimize image processing speed on edge by 10X using Matrix Vectorization.
✔ Deep Learning Workflow. Responsible for whole project pipeline: Setup and configure Basler Camera for good quality images; collect food package images; lead data annotation meeting with outsourced labeling company; build Faster R-CNN and PSPNet models which achieve more than 95% accuracy; deploy model artifacts on edge using Torch Serve.
✔ System Design. High-level design between Vision Module and Camera Software/Database/Cloud/UI Modules under across-team collaboration.
✔ Patent. One Seal Score patent is filed in work[1].

Competitive Advantages:
✔ Strong sense of key criteria to build a successful early-stage startup. Besides engineering expertise, I have knowledge in meeting product-market fit, building a strong team, and finding good pivot timing.
✔ Data is more important than models in industrial anomaly detections. I know how to leverage business power to gain high-quality data/labels and solve imbalanced data issues under limited startup resources.
✔ Customer experience at day one. Get started with customer experience and work backward toward the technology.

[1] Richard John Cisek, Wenbo Zhang. System And Method To Determine A Score Indicating Seal Integrity In A Package. [Filed at USPTO, Application Number: 17668284]

summary:
I am a passionate programmer and tech enthusiast with an unwavering belief in the power of code! I embrace challenges head-on, constantly pushing boundaries. I quickly pick up new tech skills, not just for my job, but from genuine curiosity and the desire to always learn the latest in tech.

I'm building Cactus, an AI copilot for small business owners to automate admin work. Think Jarvis for Ironman. We want to empower small business owners and solo entrepreneurs to succeed.

I've always wanted to build a product-first company that uses dead simple tech to solve a large problem. We're looking for our early founding team members who are passionate about programming, heads-down builders, and excited to create a generational company.

My fascination with technology began at a young age, and over the years, I've honed my skills across various programming languages and frameworks, including PHP, Python, Django, React, Angular, and Rails.

I lead with empathy and transparency, striving to create a culture that values compassion and open communication. Inspired by companies like Basecamp, PostHog, and GitLab, I am passionate about building products that genuinely improve people's lives without unnecessary complexity.

In my free time, I enjoy exploring new technologies, engaging in deep conversations, and spending quality time with my family. My guiding principle in both work and life is simple: "It’s Possible."

recommendations.recommenderHeadline: Co-Founder & CEO at Cactus YC X25 | 2x YC Founder | ODF 22 | Relentless Entrepreneur
recommendations.text:
I had the immense pleasure of working closely with Avinash during our time at Turing, and I continue to be amazed by his dedication, creativity, and technical prowess. Avinash is not only a brilliant technical builder but also an incredible person on a personal level.

At university, Avinash founded the Open Source club, mentoring over 100 students and driving major open source contributions. His leadership and passion for technology were evident from the start, and they have only grown stronger over the years.

One of the stories that stand out about Avinash is when he won the Sun Microsystems coding contest. Instead of taking the all-inclusive travel package for himself, he negotiated with Sun to exchange it for train tickets for his entire team of 11. This selfless act allowed his team to celebrate together and demonstrated his incredible ability to think outside the box and prioritize his team’s happiness. He inspired an entire batch of students to get into coding contests.

Technically, Avinash is a force to be reckoned with. He made significant contributions to the OpenSolaris codebase and built DefinedTerm, a platform that helps lawyers write more clearly and accurately. His work has earned him accolades, including winning the Code For Freedom contest and publishing an IEEE paper on cybersecurity knowledge empowerment.

Having known Avinash for 17 years, from our college days to our professional collaboration at Turing, I can confidently say that he is one of the most talented and dedicated individuals I have ever met. At Turing Labs, he played a pivotal role in retaining and expanding major CPG logos, delivering over $57M in business impact to R&D teams.

Beyond his technical skills, Avinash is an amazing person who exudes positivity. He firmly believes that with the right mindset and effort, anything is possible. His positive attitude and unwavering commitment make him an exceptional leader and an even better friend. Working with Avinash has been an absolute joy, and I am incredibly excited about our future endeavours together.

volunteerExperience.description:
Rotoroa Island is a serene wildlife sanctuary in Auckland’s Hauraki Gulf. In the fall of 2010, I was lucky to be one of the first on-site occupants of the island in decades — my fellow volunteers and I took care shaping the rugged terrain into walking trails, paths, and other civil projects. We led the development of construction which helped tame the wild site that has since been become home to a beloved museum and park.

"For over 100 years, Rotoroa Island was an island apart, off-limits to all but a few souls isolated there for alcohol and drug rehabilitation in the care of the Salvation Army. Today, following an extensive transformation - Rotoroa is accessible to everyone as an island sanctuary where visitors can connect with nature and be educated about conservation. The island is populated with endangered species which require intensive wildlife management."

Learn more:
http://rotoroa.org.nz/

name: Rauf Akdemir
headline: building airweave YC X25 | let agents search any app
summary: I got hit by a car a week before our YC launch. What most people don’t know is that it wasn’t even our first emergency. A month earlier, my cofounder had a life-threatening allergic reaction. He ended up in the ER, struggling to breathe. We didn’t tell YC or our angel investors. Not because we were hiding, but because we wanted to prove we could handle the pressure. We shipped features from hospital beds. Reviewed code between doctor visits. Sometimes launching means praying your cofounder lives long enough to hit deploy. We launched on time. Twice. He’s okay now and I’m okay now. And the product we built, Willow (YC X25) , didn’t just save time. It helped save us, by making my co-founder work even when he couldn't type. Try it now: WillowVoice.com

Mapiq's explicit ambition of being a product company is defining for the role of data science. As part of the then-small team I was tasked with providing the data solutions that add to the feature-richness of Mapiq's products. Having a mix of end-to-end responsibilities, most of my work went to:

- prototyping and productionisation of machine learning algorithms
- building efficient data streams & warehouses (including our transition from vanilla SQL to Delta Lakehouse architecture)
- creating custom data science solutions for high profile customers

experience.title: Data Engineer
experience.description:
As external data engineer for Captain (previously PEAX Data), I was responsible for designing and building custom-tailored solutions for clients in the AgriFood sector.

Most projects revolve around production and/or logistic optimization in the food supply chain. They follow the same pattern of pulling data from legacy systems (climate computers, greenhouse tracking systems, cameras) into the cloud, transforming it there and processing it further for (real-time) analytics or AI applications.

What excites me most about this work is the bare-metal reality of our clients’ tech stacks which in turn poses an engineering challenge for us to build pipelines that are both solid and cost-effective. It requires us to be creative with on-premise script deployments, data modelling and cloud tools on a daily basis.

experience.title: Co-Founder
experience.description: As co-founder and decision maker of Shiva Honey I mainly resided in the background, where I translated our brand vision to various stakeholders such as our production, commerical and artistical partners. Started out as a hobby project, but has become an operational business. Sold shares back to founding partners in order to refocus efforts.

experience.title: Software Engineer - Data
